title: 111_s3238
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that the tragic deaths on September 11, 2001, have forever changed the nation. The heroic actions of officers, emergency workers, and employees who responded to the attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon are recognized. The passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 are also acknowledged for their bravery in preventing further casualties. The tragic events of September 11, 2001, led to heroic actions by Americans to prevent further harm. Recognizing the sacrifices made, it is appropriate to award a medal to honor those who lost their lives to terrorism. SEC. 3. FALLEN HEROES OF 9/11 CONGRESSIONAL MEDALS. The President is authorized to award the "Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal" to individuals and organizations in recognition of their sacrifices and to honor those who died on and after September 11, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike 3 designs of medals for this purpose. The Fallen Heroes of 9/11 Congressional Medal will be awarded to those who lost their lives in the attacks at the World Trade Center, Pentagon, and Flight 93. The design of the medal will be determined after consultation with the Secretary of Defense. The medals will be silver for subsection (a)(1) and gold for subsections (2) through (4) of subsection (a). Eligibility to receive the medal will be determined. Any individual who died on or after September 11, 2001, as a direct result of the acts of terrorism within the United States on that date, shall be eligible for a medal authorized by subsection (a). Eligibility shall be determined by the Secretary in consultation with other government officials. SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS.

The Secretary will create bronze duplicates of medals for distribution to precinct houses, firehouses, and other duty stations where individuals who responded to the 9/11 attacks were assigned. These duplicates will be displayed in memory of those who perished.

SEC. 5. ESTABLISHMENT OF LISTS OF RECIPIENTS. Before the 120-day period after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary will establish lists of eligible individuals for receiving a medal and duplicate medal. Consultation with various organizations will be done to determine the recipients, and the lists will be final. The Secretary will establish lists of eligible individuals for receiving medals and duplicate medals, which are final and not subject to judicial review. If anyone becomes eligible, their name will be promptly added to the appropriate list. The Secretary may sell duplicate bronze medals to the public to cover costs. The medals struck under this Act are considered national medals.
